image.altText: A man walks through journalists and cameras.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann will be able to appeal against the result of his failed defamation case, after a Federal Court judge dismissed an application for him to pay a security of costs before any appeal goes ahead.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann cleared to proceed with defamation case appeal

image.altText: A building with mult-coloured exterior.

props.synopsis: Aleu Mapiou, found not guilty by reason of mental impairment to murdering another patient while inside the Canberra Hospital Adult Mental Health Unit, will be involuntarily detained at a secure mental health facility.

title.children: Canberra man found not guilty of murdering fellow mental health unit patient by reason of mental impairment

image.altText: Portrait of Shane Rattenbury sitting on a small wall with bushland down a mountain behind him.

props.synopsis: The ACT election saw the Greens go from six seats in the Legislative Assembly to three, with a fourth possible, but the swing against them was smaller than it appeared with the result being the party's third-best in ACT history.

title.children: ACT Greens still have 'very strong base' despite losing nearly half their Legislative Assembly seats

image.altText: Two credit card sized boxes with sexual health organisation logos, with an ultrasound probe cover in front.

props.synopsis: An independent review reveals a Canberra sexual health education organisation's mistaken distribution of more than 4,000 ultrasound probe covers as condoms was likely caused by an online ordering error.

title.children: Sexual health organisation's condom bungle caused by online ordering error

image.altText: A man in a suit speaks into multiple microphones.

props.synopsis: Re-elected MLA Jeremy Hanson says the party's seventh-straight election loss was "very disappointing", as conversations continue about Elizabeth Lee's leadership.

title.children: Jeremy Hanson confirms he will make bid for Canberra Liberals leadership, says the party has 'gone backwards'

image.altText: People walking across a courtyard surrounded by buildings.

props.synopsis: Vice-chancellor Stephen Parker says the University of Canberra is "spending beyond its means" and needs to save about $50 million in recurrent expenditure by the end of next year.

title.children: University of Canberra to cut 200 jobs as part of 'urgent and significant' cost-saving measures

image.altText: Cages at a dog pound.

props.synopsis: Pet owners are urged to protect their dogs from the deadly parvovirus by keeping their vaccinations up to date.

title.children: 'A horrible disease': Queanbeyan Pound euthanases 21 dogs after outbreak of canine parvovirus

image.altText: Mick Gentleman looking sombre.

props.synopsis: While the ACT election has been called in favour of Labor, the exact make-up of the next Legislative Assembly isn't yet certain and there is one seat still up for grabs.

title.children: One seat still in doubt in ACT election as Greens claim third

image.altText: King Charles III chats with owner of alpaca.

props.synopsis: King Charles III and Queen Camilla have landed in Australia's capital as they begin their second official day of royal engagements.

title.children: King Charles III and Queen Camilla greet alpaca, given Tim Tams in Canberra as protester arrested

image.altText: Multiple boats in ocean including Border Force patrol boat and small illegal fishing vessel

props.synopsis: Saibai Islanders say they have been left to "fend for themselves" as confrontations over illegal fishing expose flaws in border security, putting their livelihoods and safety at risk.

title.children: Islanders left to defend Australian border warn 'someone will get hurt' unless government acts

image.altText: A group of about twenty people dressed all in black with their faces covered.

props.synopsis: Police have used capsicum spray on a group of neo-Nazis who disrupted an asylum seeker rally in Melbourne's Docklands last night.

title.children: Police use capsicum spray on neo-Nazis after clash at Melbourne asylum seeker rally

image.altText: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi waive at the camera while standing in front of Indian and Chinese flags respectively

props.synopsis: Troops from China and India have been involved in a tense stand-off for years high in the Himalayas, but a new deal raises the prospect of a peaceful future.

title.children: Two nuclear-armed states have been involved in a bitter stand-off for years. Could a new deal guarantee peace?

image.altText: Hezbollah leader Hashem Safieddine

props.synopsis: On Wednesday morning, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) confirmed Safieddine died in the attack three weeks ago which also killed 25 other Hezbollah leaders.

title.children: Israel's military confirms killing of expected Hezbollah successor Hashem Safieddine

image.altText: A man with blond hair wearing a suit looks into the distance

props.synopsis: The 80-year-old is accused of baiting young men with the prospect of modelling jobs so they could be abused.

title.children: Former Abercrombie & Fitch CEO arrested on US sex trafficking charges

image.altText: Older indigenous men stand behind a wide gate labelled Kinchela Boys Home

props.synopsis: The 49 Indigenous survivors from Kinchela Boys Home want to turn the site into a museum and place of healing as they mark 100 years since the institution began operations.

title.children: Stripped naked, heads shaved and given a number to replace their name. Survivors of boys home share their stories

image.altText: New Indonesian ministers salute during their inauguration

props.synopsis: Mugiyanto thought he would die after being abducted by soldiers in 1998 when Prabowo Subianto was a powerful special forces commander. Now the former human rights advocate has joined the Indonesian president's cabinet.

title.children: Prabowo's 'fat cabinet' features active military members — and an activist kidnapped by the military

image.altText: A graphic hows two men shaking hands with blue shining behind him and red shining behind the other man.

props.synopsis: Cost of living, youth crime, health and housing have been in the spotlight ahead of Queensland's election on Saturday. Here are the major pledges that have been made.

title.children: Here's what the major parties are promising ahead of the Queensland election

image.altText: Drone image of wind turbines on coastline.

props.synopsis: Tasmania is headed for a 15-year low in its renewable energy generation — posing a threat to the state's claim of being "100 per cent renewable".

title.children: Dry spell undoes Tasmania's claim of being 100 per cent powered by green energy

image.altText: a close up of carroll

props.synopsis: Queensland's former police commissioner has been accused of striking a deal with the state's powerful police union not to release "damaging reports" they commissioned in the belief the service did not "need more bad press", according to an internal email seen by the ABC.

title.children: 'I couldn't unsee what I saw': Officers involved in unreleased review of pilot program to transform Queensland Police speak out

image.altText: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump looking at each other in election illustration

props.synopsis: The Central Park Five announce they're suing Donald Trump for defamation and Kamala Harris courts the Republican vote — here's the latest updates from the US election.

title.children: Walz says Trump 'spiralling' as former president hit with new lawsuit — the latest from the US election campaign

image.altText: King Charles at Sydney Opera House royal tour

props.synopsis: The royal couple met enthusiastic crowds at Sydney Opera House after a busy day attending a community barbecue in Parramatta, fit with sheepdogs and sausage sandwiches.

title.children: King Charles III and Queen Camilla have finished their Australian royal tour. Here's the big moments from their final day

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: Futures are pointing to a positive start for local stocks, with MinRes and WiseTech ones to watch. The corporate watchdog alleges QBE misled customers over premium discounts. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX 200 set to lift, ASIC sues QBE over insurance discounts

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: QBE apologies, says it's cooperating with ASIC
ASIC files case against QBE Insurance in Federal Court
Working for longer as mortgages bite

image.altText: A man's leg with a purple rash on it.

props.synopsis: Doctors say scurvy, best associated with sailors' lack of fresh fruit and vegetables on long sea voyages, is a "re-emerging diagnosis" — partly due to cost-of-living pressures.

title.children: Australian man diagnosed with scurvy, a disease doctors 'thought we had eradicated'

image.altText: Girl with blurred face dancing in a red tutu with elaborate gold embroidery

props.synopsis: A dance teacher tells a court a teenager whose parents are accused of starving her was at risk of fractures if she jumped too much, but the parents refused her pleas to get medical assistance for their daughter.

title.children: Teacher who raised alarm about teen with 'wafer thin' arms says parents brushed off concerns

image.altText: Writer Jodi Wilson wears a hat and scarf while walking on a beach in north-west Tasmania.

props.synopsis: Jodi Wilson thought she would return to NSW after caravanning around Australia with her family. Instead travel inspired a change of plan.

title.children: After caravanning around Australia, we bought our first home in a place I never expected

image.altText: A wide McDonald's storefront logo including the golden yellow 'M'

props.synopsis: The United States' leading public health organisation has identified 49 cases of the bacterial infection and one person has died.

title.children: US McDonald's stores linked to 'fast-moving' E. coli outbreak

image.altText: Couple cuddle in bed

props.synopsis: The "other woman" in an affair with a married man is often the subject of scorn. Three women reveal why they choose to stay with their secret lover.

title.children: 'I'm always going to be the mistress': Why these women choose to stay in secret relationships with married men

image.altText: Workers using a reach truck to repair power lines at a tall electricity tower

props.synopsis: Power has been progressively restored in the far west New South Wales town as an inquiry has been announced into how the community was left without backup electricity.

title.children: Inquiry called, power back on after backup generator failed in Broken Hill

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and glasses looks ahead

props.synopsis: The head of GFG Alliance Sanjeev Gupta says there will be no more job losses at the Whyalla steelworks, while not being able to give a firm timeline on when he expects the blast furnace to come online again.

title.children: Whyalla steelworks owner promises no more job cuts with blast furnace to be fixed in 'days or weeks'

image.altText: Wallaroos players after a loss

props.synopsis: Already drawn in the same pool as world number one England, Australia will not have to face the red-hot favourites for the 2025 Women's Rugby World Cup until the last group game.

title.children: Wallaroos avoid World Cup opener against raging favourites

image.altText: Young women's face with sunglasses on her head

props.synopsis: One in four women will experience pain during sex that can affect their self-worth and their relationships. These people say pelvis floor specialists can improve women's lives.

title.children: Sex was 'unbearable' for Daisy until she went to see a physiotherapist

image.altText: A group of dancers smile, standing together with Aboriginal face paint, holding gum leaves.

props.synopsis: A new public holiday and more oversight of government spending on Indigenous affairs are among the ideas being taken into Victoria's treaty negotiations later this year.

title.children: A new public holiday and a bigger say in Indigenous policy — what's on the table for Victoria's treaty

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe protest

props.synopsis: The fallout from Lidia Thorpe’s message to the king has made global headlines. But what do Indigenous Australians make of the interaction? From 'Not really accurate' to 'very ballsy' First Nations people weight in.

title.children: 'We've put down our spears, we're using our voice': Mob react to Lidia Thorpe

image.altText: Two images of black cockatoo's superimposed over bushland and sand mining.

props.synopsis: An Australian minerals company wants to clear about 1,000 hectares of threatened native banksia woodlands for two WA mining projects.

title.children: Sand miner's push to clear vulnerable banksia forest draws criticism from conservationists
